conclusion: Electromagnetic aircraft launch is the most advanced catapult technology for aircraft carriers, and China has reached the world's advanced level in this field.
An interest group is conducting research on the design of an electromagnetic launch system.

The mover is insulated and fixed to the coil. The coil drives the mover, which can slide without friction on the horizontal rails. The coil is located in a radial magnetic field between the rails, where the magnitude of the magnetic flux density is B.

When switch S is connected to 1, the constant current source is connected to the coil. The mover starts from rest, accelerating the aircraft. When the aircraft reaches takeoff speed, it detaches from the mover.

At this time, S is thrown to 2, connecting the fixed resistor R0. Simultaneously, a retraction force F is applied. Under the action of F and the magnetic force, the mover returns to its initial position and stops.
The v-t diagram of the mover from rest to return is shown in Figure (2).
From time t1 to t3, F=(800-10v)N, and F is removed at t3.

It is known that the takeoff speed v1=80m/s, t1=1.5s, the number of turns of the coil is n=100, the circumference of each turn is l=1m, the mass of the aircraft is M=10kg, the total mass of the mover and coil is m=5kg, R0=9.5Ω, and B=0.1T.
Air resistance and the effect of aircraft takeoff on the mover's velocity are negligible.

premise: The mover is accelerated by the magnetic force and the retraction force.
conclusion: The magnetic force is given by F = (800 - 10v)N.

premise: The net force is the sum of the magnetic force and the retraction force.
conclusion: The acceleration a can be calculated as: a = F/m = (800 - 10v)/5.

premise: The acceleration of the mover can be found by considering the net force acting on it.
conclusion: The velocity v can be found by integrating the acceleration over time.

premise: The velocity v can be found by integrating the acceleration over time.
conclusion: The velocity v can be calculated as: v = ∫ a dt = ∫ (800 - 10v)/5 dt.

premise: The time t1 can be found by integrating the velocity over time.
conclusion: The time t1 can be calculated as: t1 = ∫ v dt = ∫ (800 - 10v)/5 dt.
